repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
From commit;
**Problem:**
    Building with GCC fails with ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
    This is a cmake build. Slightly above in the log I can see the message
    neovim/src/nvim/tui/tui.c:391:21: error: passing argument 1 of 'os_tty_guess_term' \
      from incompatible pointer type [-Wincompatible-pointer-types]
    This is on GCC 15.1.0 and MSYS2.

**Solution:**
    The call to os_tty_guess_term seems to only be used behind define MSWIN,
    it accepts a const char **. making term into a const pointer lets the
    build succeed.

If there is a better fix for this failure such as build config, function declaration change, anything else please let me know and I will try it. I first noticed this issue about one or two months ago on master.

comment_data.body: Maybe we should change the retval of `os_getenv` to be `const`. This is fine for now though.

While we're here, can you delete these 2 lines. They are no longer valid since #32683.

And I think this comment also needs to be dropped: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/5cf135f9a0ac472621d133bb4a03780a7bff6640/src/nvim/os/env.c#L151-L152 cc @zeertzjq @juditnovak for sanity check :)

Ok, great. I figured it is a vendored library or similar but wasn't sure about the implications of that. I guess the function should be considered fully "owned" or part of the neovim codebase.

Maybe the function is not called that often so the change would be trivial but otoh a const argument sort of (maybe not 100% guarantees in the case of C) documents the function behavior. But I don't use C on most days so didn't want to go to deep here ðŸ˜€

Addendum: noticed now the discussion was the retval. There is a separate issue of course with freeing the const pointer.

I think `os_tty_guess_term()` needs change too. It can't just override `term` as it's now an allocated string. It needs to free the old `term` and set the new value to an allocated string instead of a constant.
True. I just checked what it does. It sets the pointed-to pointer to a statically allocated char* value. Those are not supposed to be freed with xfree but that seems likely to happen now?

term is only changed if term is a null pointer (which `os_getenv` can return). TERM is very often set though so it is unlikely to be freeing the statically allocated string (but possible?). I pushed a change which I think is safer (I don't know if the value of term is actually important. `os_tty_guess_term()` has a bunch of sideffects which might matter more than the term value. I didn't check but the behaviour should be roughly the same.).
This isn't right. If `TERM` environment variable is set, the guessed value from `os_tty_guess_term()` should not override it.

Ok. `os_tty_guess_term()` will only overwrite a NULL ptr with the new term value. But now, `os_setenv` is called regardless. Simply using a null-check before `os_setenv(...)` on row 390 would fix that, then?
I'm not sure what you are referring to. A null check for what?

So I would check if the TERM env-var was null before `os_tty_guess_term()` is called. If that was the case (term is null) I would call `os_setenv("TERM", guessed_term);`, otherwise it would keep the previous value. Not sure if this is what the comment meant. Another way to not overwrite TERM is to simply ignore the value of guessed_term (did a change now as the unit test failed with what I first pushed).

`os_tty_guess_tem` sets term if it is null regardless but checking is good form I suppose.

Edit: As os_tty_guess_tem is written now, it could just return the pointer to the static string, but I'm not sure if that would make the code better or not.
The important part is copying `guessed_term` to `term`, so that terminfo is set up properly.
xstrdup allocates a new `char*`, but the old one is not free'd, according to some strdup manpage. Not sure if xstrdup is different. Is that still ok?
I don't know what you are talking about. `guessed_term` is not allocated.
I mean that `xstrdup` would allocate a new copy of `guessed_term` which is assigned to `term`. But I don't know what happens to the old value of `term`. Asan was ok so it should be fine.
Yes, sorry that's true. I don't know know missed that. Thanks for replying.

comment_regular_data.body: I see that non-windows builds are affected here. I don't know if this would be fixed by making a separate pointer alias to be used for the call to `os_tty_guess_term` or simply making an explicit conversion. Will try it out.

```
/home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/tui/tui.c:518:9: error: passing 'const char *' to parameter of type 'void *' discards qualifiers [-Werror,-Wincompatible-pointer-types-discards-qualifiers]
  518 |   xfree(term);
```

this is just C being dumb. of course "const" is irrelevant when we want to free something. either cast the arg, or maybe `XFREE_CLEAR` avoids a cast.

I had some lint & build errors (seems not from my change?) with MSVC about needing to cast an anonymous enum to it's type (?) before using it. Hope re-running the tests a lot is not an issue or anything!

~~The test run of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34589 appears to be stuck in windows (functional) tests. It will unblock this build failure (C5287) after rebase. I am guessing there is a timeout on the job at some point but it didn't make progress for 40 minutes now.~~ It's recovered. I've rebased.

I'm considering removing the added null-check if the test fails again now. For some reason only the zig-build test run failed but I'd assume those are the same tests. This means that TERM would be overridden even if it was set in the environment from the start which is what the behaviour used to be.

EDIT: Zig build unit & functionaltest passed after rebase. Two test runs failed due to 503/500 response from github. Seems to be some flakiness that doesn't relate to anything the tests are doing (?). Between the run before & after last rebase, all tests are green now.

repo.name: neovim

labels.description: building and installing Neovim using the provided scripts
labels.name: build

title: build(win): "incompatible pointer type"
